column4: When I check the "hardware drivers" I can see an entry for Athereos HAL and another one for Athereos 892.11 wireless lan card. Does that mean it has detected the wireless properly ?
not realy, it just means that the drivers have been enabled it doesnt realy mean the driver detected your card
dmesg|grep wifi
is there an error message from the atheros hal?
wifi%d: unable to attach hardware: 'Hardware revision not supported' (HAL status 13)
seems like there's an error all right
yeah the hal doesnt support your card, what you can try is compiling the latest madwifi snapshot yourself, they have some snapshots that have a newer hal
I see. How equal are the ubuntu precompiled binaries against the source tree ?
I mean, if I got the source and just complied, would it give me the precomplied that ubuntu suplies ?
you would have to reinstall the selfbuild madwifi driver on each kernel update
That sucks a bit, having to recompile the kernel. But after all I'm thinking I don't need to follow every kernel update
once and if I have that running I guess I'll settle for that kernel revision
And moreover, recompliling the kernel on my own might mess up the nVidia drivers
its basicaly just change to the directory you downlaoded the source to, make clean;make sudo make install then reboot and it should work again
I fear I won't be able to use the nVidia drivers, which I currently use from the stock kernel binaries
sure you can, its just compiling your own kernelmodules for madwifi, you dont need to build a custom kernel for that
I see that my installation has included the package "linux-headers-2.6.24-19 which is what I currently use. Would these sufice for compling the madwifi module and HAL ?
yeah just install build-essential package and make sure the linux-header package matching your running kernel is installed, and of course download one of the snapshots that contain the newer hal
ok I'll do that. So I'm away now compiling-in-attempt :D

Compiling went flawless. In the madwifi.tar.gz there was an INSTALL file that showed a way to insert the modules created. But I gather I'd have to unload the current modules first. Is it enough to uncheck the Athereos HAL and the Athereos 802.11 entries in Administration->Hardware Drivers ?
uncheck those, but the make install target should unlaod them automaticaly usualy
Ah I see. Well anyhow I'll have to go eat first before my food break is over and then I'll continue. Thanks for the help so far mgolisch. :)
